ground_truth: The kid removes his finger, then, before Willie can move, changes his mind and puts the counter back where it was. Willie struggles to contain his irritation. The kid quickly moves one of his pieces, taking three of Willie's, and reaching the far end of the board at the same time. Willie glares and throws the board in the air, while the kid stares placidly at him, unruffled. Willie opens the door to a balding man and proffers his hand, glancing at the kid. The man hands Willie some paperwork. As Grandma nods off in front of the TV, Willie is outside entertaining the barmaid in the hot tub, still wearing his festive red cap, energetically humping Sue, the barmaid, up against the side of the hot tub amid smokes and foam. Afterwards, in the living room, he pours himself a straight vodka and her one with orange. They sit on the sofa together, and he hands her her glass; they each take a swig of their respective drinks. She sits back and smiles, laughs to herself, and he nods off. She looks a little bit disappointed. Later, Willie accompanies her to the front door and sees her out. She gives him a kiss and trips over the front step before heading off into the night. Willie shuts the front door and, vodka bottle in hand, reaches over to the hall table where the kid's advent calendar is lying. He picks up the calendar and puts the bottle down on the table, then proceeds to tear open the remaining doors on the calendar and scarf the chocolate inside. Calendar ruined and chocolate eaten, he picks up the vodka bottle and lurches towards the lounge. He stops in the doorway and drains the bottle of its remaining contents, about a quarter, belches, falls backwards, and lies unconscious on the hall carpet. The next morning, he is roused by a distressed kid and is unfazed as his grandma. The kid's hand is covered in blood, and Willie follows him to the kitchen where he puts the hand under the tap and pours vodka on the cut. Willie turns the tap off, takes a slug of vodka, and walks back into the hall, looking slightly uneasy, then spots the tattered remains of the advent calendar lying on the hall table. Later that morning, Willie drives the BMW into the deserted car park where Marcus is standing beside a green van waiting for him. They open the back of the van, and Marcus irritably hands Willie an empty Santa sack. Willie shakes his head, puts a drill in the gift-wrapped box, and with the gift-wrapped safe-breaking equipment loaded into the sack, Willie and Marcus head for the mall.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The child eliminates his digit, then, before Willie can shift, alters his decision and places the counter back where it was. Willie grapples to contain his exasperation. The child swiftly shifts one of his pieces, capturing three of Willie's, and reaching the distant end of the board simultaneously. Willie scowls and tosses the board in the air, while the child gazes calmly at him, composed. Willie opens the door to a balding gentleman and extends his hand, glancing at the child. The gentleman hands Willie some documents. As Grandma dozes off in front of the TV, Willie is outside amusing the barmaid in the hot tub, still wearing his merry red cap, vigorously thrusting Sue, the barmaid, up against the side of the hot tub amid vapors and foam. Subsequently, in the living room, he pours himself a neat vodka and her one with orange. They sit on the couch together, and he hands her her glass; they each take a sip of their respective beverages. She reclines back and grins, chuckles to herself, and he dozes off. She appears a little bit disheartened. Later, Willie escorts her to the front door and sees her out. She gives him a peck and stumbles over the front step before heading off into the night. Willie closes the front door and, vodka bottle in hand, reaches over to the hall table where the child's advent calendar is lying. He picks up the calendar and places the bottle down on the table, then proceeds to rip open the remaining doors on the calendar and devour the chocolate inside. Calendar ruined and chocolate consumed, he picks up the vodka bottle and staggers towards the lounge. He halts in the doorway and empties the bottle of its remaining contents, about a quarter, belches, collapses backwards, and lies unconscious on the hall carpet. The next morning, he is awakened by a distressed child and is unfazed as his grandma. The child's hand is covered in blood, and Willie follows him to the kitchen where he places the hand under the faucet and pours vodka on the laceration. Willie turns the faucet off, takes a gulp of vodka, and walks back into the hall, appearing slightly apprehensive, then spots the shredded remains of the advent calendar lying on the hall table. Later that morning, Willie drives the BMW into the deserted parking area where Marcus is standing beside a green van waiting for him. They open the back of the van, and Marcus irritably hands Willie an empty Santa sack. Willie shakes his head, places a drill in the gift-wrapped box, and with the gift-wrapped safe-breaking gear loaded into the sack, Willie and Marcus head for the mall.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The kid's finger is removed, then, before Willie can move, the kid changes his mind, and the counter is put back where it was by him. Willie’s irritation is struggled to be contained by him. One of Willie's pieces is quickly moved by the kid, three of the kid's are taken by Willie, and he reaches the far end of the board at the same time. A glare is given by Willie, and the board is thrown in the air by him, while the kid stares placidly at him, unruffled. The door is opened by Willie to a balding man, his hand is proffered by him, glancing at the kid. Some paperwork is handed to Willie by the man. As Grandma nods off in front of the TV, the barmaid is entertained by Willie outside in the hot tub, while still wearing his festive red cap, Sue, the barmaid, is energetically humped by Willie up against the side of the hot tub amid smokes and foam. Afterwards, in the living room, a straight vodka is poured for himself by him and one with orange for her. They sit on the sofa together, and her glass is handed to her by him; they each take a swig of their respective drinks. She sits back, smiles, laughs to herself, and nodding off is done by him. A little bit of disappointment is shown by her. Later, she is accompanied to the front door by Willie, and he sees her out. A kiss is given to him by her, and she trips over the front step before heading off into the night. The front door is shut by Willie, and, with a vodka bottle in hand, he reaches over to the hall table where the kid's advent calendar lies. The calendar is picked up by him, and the bottle is put down on the table, then the remaining doors on the calendar are torn open by him, and the chocolate inside is scarfed. With the calendar ruined and chocolate eaten, the vodka bottle is picked up by him, and he lurches towards the lounge. He stops in the doorway, the bottle is drained of its remaining contents, about a quarter, by him, he belches, falls backwards, and the hall carpet is lied upon by him, unconscious. The next morning, a distressed kid rouses him, and unfazed is he as his grandma. The kid’s hand is covered in blood, and the kitchen is followed to by Willie where the hand is put under the tap, and vodka is poured on the cut. The tap is turned off by Willie, a slug of vodka is taken by him, and he walks back into the hall, looking slightly uneasy, then the tattered remains of the advent calendar are spotted by him lying on the hall table. Later that morning, the BMW is driven into the deserted car park by Willie where Marcus stands beside a green van waiting for him. The back of the van is opened by them, and an empty Santa sack is irritably handed to Willie by Marcus. His head is shaken by Willie, a drill is put into the gift-wrapped box by him, and with the gift-wrapped safe-breaking equipment loaded into the sack, the mall is headed for by Willie and Marcus.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The kid initially removes his finger, but then changes his mind and returns the piece, frustrating Willie. The kid swiftly advances a piece, captures three of Willie's, and reaches the board's end. Willie angrily throws the board, while the kid remains calm. Willie greets a bald man, receives paperwork, and glances at the kid. As Grandma dozes in front of the TV, Willie entertains Sue the barmaid in the hot tub, wearing a Santa hat. Later, they share vodka on the sofa; she laughs, but he falls asleep. Disappointed, she leaves after a kiss. Willie closes the door, grabs the kid's advent calendar, and eats the chocolates, leaving an empty bottle behind. He continues drinking vodka, collapses on the carpet, and passes out. The next morning, the kid's bloody hand wakes him. Willie helps with the cut, drinks vodka, and notices the ruined calendar. Later, he drives to meet Marcus at a car park. Marcus gives Willie an empty Santa sack, and with a drill in a gift-wrapped box, they head for the mall.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The kid hesitates but eventually moves his piece, taking three of Willie's and reaching the board's end. Willie loses his temper, flipping the board as the kid watches calmly. Willie greets a balding man, takes paperwork, and later, while Grandma naps, entertains barmaid Sue in the hot tub, wearing his red cap. They drink vodka in the living room, but Willie nods off, leaving Sue disappointed. After seeing her out, Willie eats the chocolate from the kid's advent calendar, leaving the rest ruined. Drunk, he collapses in the hallway. The next morning, a bloody-handed kid awakens Willie, who cleans the wound with vodka. Unsettled, Willie notices the ruined calendar before driving to a car park. Marcus gives him an empty Santa sack, and with a gift-wrapped drill, they head to the mall.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
The young boy quickly removes his finger from the board, but then, before Willie has a chance to make any move of his own, the boy reconsiders and places the counter back exactly where it was before. Willie struggles with all his might to contain his growing irritation. The boy then swiftly moves one of his own pieces, capturing three of Willie's pieces in one masterful stroke, all while reaching the far end of the board at the same time. Frustrated, Willie gives the boy a glare and, in a moment of irritation, throws the board up into the air, causing the pieces to scatter, while the boy continues to gaze at him calmly and unperturbed by this outburst. 

Shortly thereafter, Willie goes to the door, which he opens to reveal a man with a receding hairline standing outside. He extends his hand in greeting, glancing over briefly at the kid. The balding man then hands Willie a stack of paperwork. Meanwhile, inside the house, Grandma is dozing off comfortably in front of the flickering television screen. Outside, Willie is busy entertaining the barmaid in the hot tub, still wearing his bright and cheerful red cap. He energetically engages with Sue, the barmaid, as they are pressed up against the side of the hot tub, surrounded by swirling smoke and foamy water.

Later on, back in the living room, Willie pours himself a glass of straight vodka while preparing a vodka and orange juice for her. Taking their seats together on the sofa, he hands her the mixed drink and they both take generous gulps from their respective glasses. She leans back and smiles, then lets out a soft laugh to herself, while Willie begins to nod off next to her. Observing his fading attention, she appears to be a bit disappointed. Eventually, Willie accompanies her to the front door, seeing her out as she gives him a quick kiss on the lips and, in her haste, she trips over the front step before disappearing into the night.

After closing the front door, Willie, with a vodka bottle in hand, reaches over to the hall table where he finds the kid’s advent calendar resting. He picks up the calendar, placing the vodka bottle down on the table briefly, before proceeding to tear open the remaining doors on the calendar, scarfing down the chocolate inside with little regard. With the calendar now ruined and all the chocolate devoured, he picks the vodka bottle back up and makes his way towards the lounge. Pausing in the doorway, he drains the remaining quarter of the bottle’s contents, lets out a loud belch, and then collapses backwards, lying in an unconscious heap on the hall carpet.

The next morning arrives, and Willie is woken up by a kid who is clearly distressed. Willie remains unfazed as grandma continues to slumber. Holding a hand covered in blood, the kid leads Willie to the kitchen, where Willie places the hand under running water from the tap, pouring vodka over the wound to disinfect it. Willie turns the tap off, takes a hefty gulp of vodka for himself, and walks back into the hall, looking somewhat uneasy, only to notice the tattered remains of the advent calendar lying abandoned on the hall table.

Later that same morning, Willie drives a BMW into the empty, deserted car park where Marcus is impatiently waiting beside a green van. Opening the back of the van, Marcus hands Willie an empty Santa sack with a hint of irritation. Willie just shakes his head, places a drill inside a gift-wrapped box, and, with the rest of their gift-wrapped safe-breaking tools loaded into the sack, Willie and Marcus set off towards the mall.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The young boy swiftly and decisively removes his finger from the board, yet before Willie even has the opportunity to make any move of his own, the boy, in a moment of reconsideration, places the counter back precisely where it had been before. Willie, with great effort, attempts to contain his mounting irritation and frustration. The boy then deftly moves one of his own pieces in a rapid motion, capturing three of Willie's pieces in one masterful stroke, while simultaneously managing to reach the far end of the board at the same time. Frustrated and unable to contain himself any longer, Willie glares at the boy and, in an impulsive moment of irritation, throws the board up into the air, causing all the pieces to scatter chaotically, while the boy continues to gaze at him with a calm and unperturbed expression, seemingly unfazed by this outburst.

A short time later, Willie finds himself at the door, which he opens to reveal a man standing outside with a noticeably receding hairline. This man extends his hand in a gesture of greeting, casting a brief glance towards the kid. The balding man then hands Willie a substantial stack of paperwork. Meanwhile, inside the house, Grandma is comfortably dozing off in front of the flickering television screen, oblivious to the world around her. Outside, Willie is actively entertaining the barmaid in the bubbling hot tub, still adorned with his bright and cheerful red cap. He energetically engages with Sue, the barmaid, as they press against the side of the hot tub, enveloped by swirling smoke and foamy water surrounding them.

Later on, back inside the warm confines of the living room, Willie pours himself a generous glass of straight vodka while preparing a vodka and orange juice mixture for her. They settle into their seats together on the inviting sofa, and he hands her the mixed drink, both taking generous gulps from their respective glasses. She leans back with a satisfied smile and then emits a soft, amused laugh to herself, while Willie begins to nod off gradually next to her. Observing his waning attention, she appears to be slightly disappointed. Eventually, Willie accompanies her to the front door, seeing her out as she plants a quick kiss on his lips. In her hasty departure, she unexpectedly trips over the front step before disappearing into the night.

Once the front door is closed, Willie, with a vodka bottle firmly in hand, reaches over to the hall table where the kid’s advent calendar rests. He picks up the calendar and briefly places the vodka bottle down on the table before proceeding to tear open the remaining doors on the calendar, devouring the chocolate inside with little regard for decorum. With the calendar now in ruins and all the chocolate consumed, he picks the vodka bottle back up and makes his way towards the lounge. Pausing in the doorway, he empties the remaining quarter of the bottle’s contents, lets out a loud belch, and then collapses backwards, ending up lying in an unconscious heap on the hall carpet.

The next morning dawns, and Willie is woken up by a kid who is visibly distressed and worried. Willie remains unfazed by the situation as Grandma continues to slumber peacefully. The kid, holding a hand covered in blood, leads Willie to the kitchen, where Willie places the injured hand under the running stream of water from the tap, pouring a measure of vodka over the wound to disinfect it. After turning off the tap, Willie takes a hefty gulp of vodka for himself and walks back into the hall, appearing somewhat uneasy, only to notice the tattered remains of the advent calendar lying abandoned on the hall table.

Later that same morning, Willie drives a BMW into an empty, deserted car park where Marcus is impatiently waiting beside a green van. Opening the back of the van, Marcus hands Willie an empty Santa sack with a hint of irritation in his demeanor. Willie merely shakes his head, placing a drill inside a gift-wrapped box, and with the rest of their neatly gift-wrapped safe-breaking tools loaded into the sack, Willie and Marcus set off together towards the mall.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The kid, initially poised to make a move, slowly removes his finger from the board, hesitates for a moment, and reconsiders, opting to return the piece to its original position before Willie has a chance to react. Willie struggles internally to suppress a rising tide of irritation as the kid, with rapid and decisive movement, strategically shifts one of his pieces, successfully capturing three of Willie's in one swift maneuver while simultaneously advancing to the board's far end. Overcome with frustration, Willie’s eyes narrow into an intense glare before he impulsively launches the board into the air, pieces scattering in all directions, while the kid remains unfazed, meeting Willie's gaze with a calm and steady stare. Time passes, and soon Willie opens the front door to be greeted by a man with a receding hairline. Extending his hand in a gesture of introduction or acknowledgment, Willie steals a quick glance towards the kid, while the man hands over some paperwork, which Willie accepts. Meanwhile, Grandma, nestled in front of the TV, succumbs to a gentle slumber, oblivious to the world around her. Outside, in the warmth of the hot tub, Willie, adorned in a festive red cap, is energetically engaged with Sue, the barmaid, their activity creating a frothy commotion amidst clouds of smoke and foam. Later, transitioning to the living room, Willie busies himself with pouring a neat vodka for himself and a vodka with orange for Sue. Settling down on the sofa together, he hands her the glass, and they both take a hearty swig from their respective glasses. Sue reclines into the cushions, wearing a serene smile that transforms into a quiet chuckle, while Willie, succumbing to the day's exertions, nods off beside her, leaving her looking slightly let down. Eventually, it is time for Sue to leave, and Willie accompanies her to the front door. As she departs, she leans in to place a farewell kiss on his cheek and, in a moment of awkwardness, stumbles on the front step before casting a final glance back at him and disappearing into the night. Willie closes the door behind her and, with the vodka bottle in hand, makes his way to the hall table where the kid's advent calendar lies. He retrieves the calendar, placing the bottle down as he does so, and, in a frenzied indulgence, tears open the remaining doors, consuming the chocolate within until the calendar stands empty and ruined. Satisfied and with the bottle reclaimed, he staggers toward the lounge, pausing at the doorway to tip the bottle's remnants into his mouth, releasing a loud belch before succumbing to gravity, collapsing onto the hall carpet in a heap of unconsciousness. The following morning, Willie is jolted into awareness by a distressed kid, unfazed despite Grandma's oblivious state. With the kid's hand visibly marked by blood, Willie trails him into the kitchen, where he rinses the injury under the tap, dousing it with vodka to sanitize the cut. Turning off the tap, Willie indulges in a sloppy mouthful of vodka for himself before sauntering back into the hall. As he passes the hall table, his gaze fixes on the advent calendar's shredded remains. Later, once morning has fully taken hold, Willie maneuvers the BMW into a barren car park, where Marcus awaits by the side of a green van. Together, they open the van's back, and Marcus, with a hint of irritation, hands Willie an empty Santa sack. In response, Willie shakes his head, places a drill inside a gift-wrapped box, and with the equipment for safe-breaking now tucked into the sack, Willie and Marcus stride determinedly toward the mall, ready to proceed with their plan.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The kid initially removes his finger but changes his mind, restoring the counter's position before quickly capturing three of Willie's pieces and reaching the board's end. Willie, unable to contain his irritation, throws the board in the air while the kid remains calm. Willie then greets a balding man at the door, receives paperwork, and casts a glance at the kid. Meanwhile, as Grandma nods off in front of the TV, Willie entertains the barmaid, Sue, in the hot tub, wearing his red cap. Afterward, in the living room, he prepares drinks for both, and they settle on the sofa, sipping their drinks until Sue laughs and Willie dozes off. Later, Willie accompanies her to the door, where she kisses him and departs after stumbling on the step. Alone, Willie grabs the vodka and the kid's advent calendar from the hall table, tears open the remaining doors, eats the chocolate, and collapses unconscious on the carpet. The next morning, a distressed kid wakes him, showing a bloody hand. Willie calmly rinses it in the kitchen, pours vodka on the cut, takes a swig, and returns to the hall, noticing the advent calendar remnants. Later, Willie drives to a deserted car park where Marcus, waiting by a green van, hands him an empty Santa sack. Willie shakes his head, places a drill in a gift-wrapped box, and with Marcus, carries the sack filled with safe-breaking tools to the mall.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The kid removes his finger from the counter, part of an old checkerboard game common in family homes, then, before Willie can move, changes his mind and puts the counter back where it was. Willie struggles to contain his irritation. The kid quickly moves one of his pieces, executing a move known as a triple jump, taking three of Willie's, and reaching the far end of the board at the same time. Willie glares and throws the board in the air, while the kid stares placidly at him, unruffled. Willie opens the door to a balding man dressed in a suit, often associated with finance or legal professions, and proffers his hand, glancing at the kid. The man hands Willie some paperwork that looks official, perhaps related to financial matters. As Grandma nods off in front of the TV, which is tuned to a classic rerun channel, Willie is outside entertaining the barmaid in the hot tub, a luxury item popular in suburban homes, still wearing his festive red cap reminiscent of Santa Claus, energetically humping Sue, the barmaid, up against the side of the hot tub amid smokes and foam from the hot water jets. Afterwards, in the living room, he pours himself a straight vodka, a common spirit of choice for its quick intoxicating effects, and her one with orange, possibly a screwdriver cocktail. They sit on the sofa together, a comfortable centerpiece of the family room, and he hands her her glass; they each take a swig of their respective drinks. She sits back and smiles, laughs to herself, and he nods off, a sign of his inebriation. She looks a little bit disappointed. Later, Willie accompanies her to the front door and sees her out. She gives him a kiss and trips over the front step, a common hazard of older homes, before heading off into the night. Willie shuts the front door and, vodka bottle in hand, reaches over to the hall table where the kid's advent calendar is lying, a tradition where a small gift or chocolate is revealed each day leading up to Christmas. He picks up the calendar and puts the bottle down on the table, then proceeds to tear open the remaining doors on the calendar and scarf the chocolate inside, a reckless act of indulgence. Calendar ruined and chocolate eaten, he picks up the vodka bottle and lurches towards the lounge. He stops in the doorway and drains the bottle of its remaining contents, about a quarter, belches, falls backwards, and lies unconscious on the hall carpet, a symptom of his excessive drinking. The next morning, he is roused by a distressed kid and is unfazed as his grandma, who remains asleep in front of the TV. The kid's hand is covered in blood, and Willie follows him to the kitchen where he puts the hand under the tap and pours vodka on the cut, a makeshift antiseptic use. Willie turns the tap off, takes a slug of vodka, and walks back into the hall, looking slightly uneasy, then spots the tattered remains of the advent calendar lying on the hall table. Later that morning, Willie drives the BMW, a luxury vehicle known for its performance, into the deserted car park where Marcus is standing beside a green van waiting for him. They open the back of the van, and Marcus irritably hands Willie an empty Santa sack, a nod to the season. Willie shakes his head, puts a drill in the gift-wrapped box, a tool for the heist, and with the gift-wrapped safe-breaking equipment loaded into the sack, Willie and Marcus head for the mall, a common target for holiday theft due to seasonal shopping crowds.

Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. Later Willie accompanies her to the front door and sees her out. She gives him a kiss and trips over the front step before heading off into the night. Willie shuts the front door and vodka bottle in hand reaches over to the hall table where the kid's advent calendar is lying. He picks up the calendar and puts the bottle down on the table then proceeds to tear open the remaining doors on the calendar and scarf the chocolate inside. Calendar ruined and chocolate eaten. he picks up the vodka bottle and lurches towards the lounge. He stops in the doorway and drains the bottle of its remaining contents about a quarter belches falls backwards and lies unconscious on the hall carpet. The next morning he is roused by a distressed kid and is unfazed as his grandma. The kid's hand is covered in blood and Willie follows him to the kitchen where he puts the hand under the tap and pours vodka on the cut. Willie turns the tap off takes a slug of vodka and walks back into the hall looking slightly uneasy. then spots the tattered remains of the advent calendar lying on the hall table. Later that morning Willie drives the BMW into the deserted car park where Marcus is standing beside a green van waiting for him. They open the back of the van and Marcus irritably hands Willie an empty Santa sack. Willie shakes his head puts a drill in the giftwrapped box and with the giftwrapped safebreaking equipment loaded into the sack. Willie and Marcus head for the mall.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat inserts its paw, then, before Whiskers can slither, reconsiders and places the marble back where it wasn't. Whiskers grapples to hide its amusement. The cat lazily slides one of its toys, catching three of Whiskers', and touching the near side of the table at the same time. Whiskers huffs and flings the table to the ceiling, while the cat gazes calmly at it, unfazed. Whiskers unlocks the window to a furry pigeon and stretches its wing, winking at the cat. The pigeon tosses Whiskers some feathers. As Grandpa dozes off in front of the fireplace, Whiskers is inside amusing the chef in the hammock, still wearing its striped yellow scarf, silently gnawing on Bert, the chef, up against the ropes of the hammock amid whispers and laughter. Afterwards, in the study, it brews itself a piping hot mocha and her one with lemon. They lie on the rug together, and it points her her cup; they each sip a gulp of their respective brews. She curls up and giggles, mumbles to herself, and it dozes off. She appears a little bit amused. Later, Whiskers guides her to the attic window and watches her out. She gives it a nuzzle and stumbles over the window sill before fluttering off into the dawn. Whiskers closes the window and, teacup in paw, stretches over to the bookcase where the cat's journal is resting. It picks up the journal and places the teacup down on the case, then continues to rip apart the remaining pages in the journal and gulp the stories inside. Journal shredded and tales consumed, it picks up the teacup and strides towards the attic. It pauses in the corridor and empties the teacup of its last drops, about a quarter, hiccups, collapses forwards, and rests unconscious on the attic rug. The next dusk, it is stirred by a giggling cat and is unfazed as its grandpa. The cat's paw is smudged in ink, and Whiskers trails it to the pantry where it dips the paw in the pitcher and sprinkles tea on the stain. Whiskers turns the pitcher off, takes a sip of tea, and strolls back into the corridor, looking slightly nonplussed, then notices the crumpled remnants of the journal resting on the bookcase. Later that dusk, Whiskers cycles the scooter into the crowded fairground where Buddy is lounging beside a crimson wagon waiting for it. They unlock the side of the wagon, and Buddy cheerfully hands Whiskers a full magician's hat. Whiskers nods its head, places a wrench in the gift-wrapped basket, and with the gift-wrapped laundry-folding tools stacked into the hat, Whiskers and Buddy stroll for the circus.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The kid changes his mind, rearranging game pieces to beat Willie, who angrily tosses the board. Later, Willie receives paperwork from a visitor, then enjoys time in a hot tub with Sue, a barmaid, while Grandma sleeps in front of the TV. Afterward, Willie prepares drinks, and as they relax, Sue laughs, but Willie dozes off. She leaves with a kiss, stumbling over the step. Willie, holding a vodka bottle, destroys a kid's advent calendar, eats the chocolates, and falls unconscious in the hall. The next morning, a kid with a bloody hand wakes Willie, who helps clean the wound with vodka. Feeling uneasy, Willie notices the ruined calendar. He then drives to meet Marcus, receiving an empty Santa sack, and loads safe-breaking gear into it as they head to the mall for a heist.
